data.title: Bringing it home. Wallace's Harris comes up big in the
data.meta_description: EAST CHICAGO - Surrounded by a multitude of well-wishers, Lew Wallace head
data.text:
EAST CHICAGO - Surrounded by a multitude of well-wishers, Lew Wallace head

coach John Hoover basked in the light of victory. Standing in the middle of the

E.C. Central gym, his smile was like a beacon.

His Hornets had just survived Hammond in a regional title thriller, 68-64.

In just his first full season as a head coach, Hoover watched a dream

crystalize.

Like a square dance in a cemetery, Hoover found a way to dance in the shadow

of certain death. With Hammond's Keith Herron sticking the shovel in the soil

for most of the second half, the Hornets found extended life.

Survival came in the name of Jamil Harris. After a first half in which

Wallace was 0 for 11 from 3-point land - a place they'd succeeded all year -

Hoover made the adjustment and took the ball inside. Harris, a senior center,

scored a game-high 27 points.

Lew Wallace (18-6) had survived the Gary Sectional. It had endured a tough

Merrillville team in Saturday's first semifinal. And barely breathing against

the upset-minded Wildcats, the Hornets simply found a way.

"God, they (Hammond) scared me to death," Hoover said with a fearful smile.

"They have improved so much. (Herron) is so quick I wasn't sure if we could

contain him.

"We had to make an adjustment at the half. I raised holy hell and told my

guys to stop shooting the 3-pointer. Maybe playing two games in one day our

kids' arms were tired. I don't know. But our perimeter shooting killed us in

the first half."

Hammond (17-7) led 33-31 at the break. Heady guard play by Herring -

steadily trying to slow the game's pace - and tough, blue-collar paint play by

Charles Robinson, 10 first half points, inspired the 'Cats.

And in a second half that was far from a "flatliner," the Wildcats extended

their lead to 51-47 going into the fourth and fateful quarter. There were four

ties and eight lead changes in the last quarter.

And the final wasn't resolved until a game-tying Herring 3-pointer with 3

seconds left caromed off the rim and was corraled by Wallace's Terrence Hayes.

"Their big kids really hurt us," Hammond coach George Green said. "In a game

like this you try and defend certain things. You have to give Coach Hoover and

his kids some credit. They made the adjustments at the half and started

pounding the ball inside.

"We tried to control the tempo, but their kids did a great job of picking

the game up."

With twin Torrence Hayes in foul trouble for much of the second half,

Terrence made it hard to miss him. And without a program, who could tell anyway?

Terrence Hayes finished with 21 points for the Hornets, who'll make their

first trip to Lafayette since 1986. He too joined in the second-life

celebration at game's end.

"We love playing in front of a crowd like this," Terrence Hayes said. "This

is the best feeling in the world. We've said all year, 'Never say die.' And

that's how we played tonight. We'll never give up.

"So everyone from Lew Wallace can gas up their cars because we're going to

Lafayette."

Hammond was led by Herron's 16 points. Robinson finished with 14 and Bob

Delano played big in the middle with 13 points and 11 rebounds.

But despite the valiant play of the 'Cats - who haven't won a regional since

1954 - it was the Hornets who once again avoided the Reaper.

"I'm just happy to get out of here alive," Hoover said before being carried

away by a throng of happy fans.

HAMMOND (64)

Jermaine Boyette 3 2-2 10, Batiste Haywood 4 1-3 9, Keith Herron 7 1-3 16,

Bob Delano 5 3-3 13, Charles Robinson 7 0-1 14, Christopher Moore 1 0-0 2, Dan

Snyder 0 0-0 0, Damon Brown 0 0-0 0. Totals - 27 7-12 64.

LEW WALLACE (68)

Ben Coleman 2 0-0 4, Maurice McCullum 1 0-1 2, Terrence Hayes 9 2-3 21,

Torrence Hayes 7 0-2 14, Jamil Harris 11 5-7 27, Carl Redfield 0 0-0 0, Keith

Murrell 0 0-0 0, Daniel Doss 0 0-0 0. Totals - 30 7-13 68.

SCORING BY QUARTERS

Hammond 16 17 18 13 - 64

Lew Wallace 17 14 16 21 - 68

3-point field goals: Herron, Boyette 2 (H), Te. Hayes (LW). Rebound leaders:

Delano 11 (H), Te. Hayes, Harris 9 (LW) Assist leaders: Herron 6 (H), Coleman 7

(LW). Team fouls: Hammond 16, Lew Wallace 14. Fouled out: Delano (H), To. Hayes

(LW). Records: Lew Wallace 18-6, Hammond 17-7.
